text:
Schema 
• Chunk fields: chunk_id, title, goal, muscle_group, ranked_exercises, programming_notes, 
keywords, citations.arxiv 
• Chunking guidance: keep chunks semantically coherent, 200–500 tokens, and richly tagged 
with domain-specific metadata for robust retrieval and filtering.dataforest 
• Citations: include per-bullet citations to the strongest available comparative trials, systematic 
reviews, or technique reviews supporting exercise selection and ranking.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
Chunks 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-001 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Chest 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Chest 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Barbell bench press (flat): stable load progression, full-chest stimulus; supported by 
technique/variation research and equivalence to push-ups when load and effort are 
matched.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
2. Dumbbell bench press (flat): greater individualized ROM and long-length tension 
potential while maintaining loadability.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
3. Incline barbell/dumbbell press: upper-pec bias with comparable global hypertrophy 
when volume matched.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
4. Weighted push-up variants: similar hypertrophy to bench press under equate

mparable global hypertrophy 
when volume matched.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
4. Weighted push-up variants: similar hypertrophy to bench press under equated 
external load and proximity to failure.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Cable fly (behind-body/slight incline): long-length emphasis with continuous tension 
for regional pec targeting.journal.iusca+1 
•  
6. Machine chest press: high-tension sets near failure with stability for volume 
accumulation.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
7. Dip (forward lean): heavy compound accessory with substantial pec loading and 
progression potential.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
8. Smith press (flat/incline): consistent bar path and ROM to support high-effort sets 
safely.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Prioritize at least one long-length movement (deep press or cable fly) plus one high-load 
press for comprehensive regional development.journal.iusca+1 
• Use proximity-to-failure on later sets and manage rest ≥60–90 s to maintain rep quality 
under hypertrophy volumes.frontiersin+1 
keywords: chest, pecs, bench press, incline, dumbbell press, push-up, cable fly, dip, smith 
press.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
citations:.pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih+5 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START

incline, dumbbell press, push-up, cable fly, dip, smith 
press.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
citations:.pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih+5 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-002 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Back and Lats 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Back and Lats 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Weighted pull-up/chin-up: heavy vertical pull with strong lat and arm stimulus and 
clear load progression.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
2. Lat pulldown (various grips): programmable intensity with transfer to vertical pulling 
performance markers.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
3. Chest-supported row (machine/free weight): high back tension with reduced spinal 
fatigue for quality hypertrophy sets.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. One-arm dumbbell row: long ROM and targeted scapular control to bias lats and 
mid-back.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Seated cable row: adjustable torso angle to balance lat and mid-back development 
across rep ranges.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
6. Barbell bent-over row: high-load horizontal pull when bracing capacity permits 
proximity to failure.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
7. Pullover (machine/cable): emphasizes shoulder extension to reduce elbow flexor 
confound when targeting lats.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih

mc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
7. Pullover (machine/cable): emphasizes shoulder extension to reduce elbow flexor 
confound when targeting lats.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Combine one vertical and one horizontal pull for comprehensive lat and mid-back 
development with stable overloading.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Adjust grips and torso angle to access different shoulder adduction/extension vectors and 
reduce joint stress while maintaining effort.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: lats, latissimus dorsi, pull-up, pulldown, rows, pullover, vertical pull, horizontal 
row.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
citations:.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-003 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Shoulders (Deltoids) 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Shoulders 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Cable lateral raise (behind-body or slight forward lean): long-length medial-delt 
tension with continuous load across ROM.journal.iusca+1 
•  
2. Dumbbell lateral raise (incline/lying variants): maintain lengthened tension and 
reduce momentum for targeted stimulus.journal.iusca+1 
•  
3. Seated overhead press (barbell/dumbbell): global deltoid mass builder with high 
loadability and joint stabil

argeted stimulus.journal.iusca+1 
•  
3. Seated overhead press (barbell/dumbbell): global deltoid mass builder with high 
loadability and joint stability.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Machine lateral raise: consistent resistance profile and fatigue-friendly high-volume 
work.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Reverse fly (cable/machine): posterior deltoid emphasis with setups that increase 
starting length.journal.iusca+1 
•  
6. Landmine press or high-incline press: anterior delt loading with shoulder-friendly bar 
path.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Pair one long-length lateral raise with a heavy press to develop medial and anterior deltoid 
while spreading joint stress.journal.iusca+1 
• Use cables/machines when fatigue or technique drift undermines lengthened tension in later 
sets.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: deltoids, lateral raise, overhead press, reverse fly, anterior delt, medial delt, 
posterior delt.journal.iusca+1 
citations:.journal.iusca+1 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-004 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Biceps 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Biceps 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Incline dumbbell curl: shoulder extension increases long-length biceps

gs — Biceps 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Biceps 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Incline dumbbell curl: shoulder extension increases long-length biceps tension for 
potential regional hypertrophy benefits.journal.iusca+1 
•  
2. Cable curl (arm slightly behind torso): sustained lengthened tension with 
controllable resistance profile.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
3. EZ-bar curl: stable mid-range heavy sets and easy progression for overall arm 
mass.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Chin-up (supinated): compound heavy loading that augments biceps along with back 
musculature.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Preacher curl: supported setup for controlled mid-to-short range 
emphasis.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Combine one long-length curl and one heavier mid-range curl to cover regional stimuli while 
ensuring proximity to failure on later sets.journal.iusca+1 
• Use cables to maintain tension when dumbbells become momentum-limited at high 
fatigue.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: biceps, curls, incline curl, cable curl, EZ-bar curl, preacher, chin-up.journal.iusca+1 
citations:.journal.iusca+1 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START ===

title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Triceps 
goal: H

nal.iusca+1 
citations:.journal.iusca+1

=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-005 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Triceps 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Triceps 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Overhead triceps extension (cable/dumbbell): long head bias via shoulder flexion 
and long-length tension.journal.iusca+1 
•  
2. Cable pushdown (rope/bar): mid-range triceps loading with easy volume 
accumulation.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
3. Close-grip bench press: high absolute loads with strong triceps involvement and 
pressing specificity.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
4. Machine dip: stable heavy accessory engaging triceps and chest at high 
effort.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Skull crusher/JM press: targeted long head and lateral head loading with careful 
elbow management.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
6. Cross-body cable extension: posterior-lateral head emphasis with continuous 
tension.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Ensure at least one overhead pattern weekly to emphasize the long head, complemented by 
a heavy press or pushdown volume.journal.iusca+1 
• Modulate elbow stress by rotating grips, cables, and angles while keeping sets near failure 
for hypertrophy.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih

ume.journal.iusca+1 
• Modulate elbow stress by rotating grips, cables, and angles while keeping sets near failure 
for hypertrophy.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: triceps, long head, pushdown, overhead extension, close-grip bench, dips, skull 
crusher.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+2 
citations:.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+2 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-006 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Quads 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Quadriceps 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. High-bar back squat to depth: comprehensive quad development with strong loading 
potential and robust thigh growth in trials.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
2. Front squat: quad-dominant variant with upright torso and deep knee flexion for 
targeted hypertrophy.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
3. Hack squat (machine): stable deep-knee flexion with spine-friendly support to push 
effective reps.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Leg press (deep ROM): effective for lower-limb hypertrophy and scalable volume 
when barbell tolerance is limited.sciencedirect+1 
•  
5. Bulgarian split squat (long stride): long-length quad loading with unilateral balance 
and range.journal.iusca+1 
•  
6. Leg extension (lengthened partials optional): distal/rectus emph

: long-length quad loading with unilateral balance 
and range.journal.iusca+1 
•  
6. Leg extension (lengthened partials optional): distal/rectus emphasis and terminal 
knee extension strength.journal.iusca+1 
programming_notes: 
• Pair one deep bilateral squat/press with a unilateral or leg extension movement to cover 
long-length and terminal range.journal.iusca+1 
• Maintain controlled tempo and adequate rest to protect ROM depth and rep quality under 
hypertrophy volumes.frontiersin+1 
keywords: quads, squat, front squat, hack squat, leg press, split squat, leg 
extension.sciencedirect+2 
citations:.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+6 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-007 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Hamstrings 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Hamstrings 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Romanian deadlift: long-length hip extensor and hamstring loading with strong 
posterior-chain stimulus.sciencedirect+1 
•  
2. Seated leg curl: hip flexion lengthens hamstrings proximally, improving long-length 
stimulus.sciencedirect+1 
•  
3. Lying leg curl: mid-length loading for higher-rep hypertrophy sets in a stable 
position.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Good morning: heavier hinge acces

3. Lying leg curl: mid-length loading for higher-rep hypertrophy sets in a stable 
position.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Good morning: heavier hinge accessory when progression and lumbar tolerance 
allow.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Single-leg RDL: increased ROM control and side-to-side balance with long-length 
bias.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
6. 45° hip extension: targeted hip extension with hamstring emphasis via hinge 
patterning.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Combine a hip-hinge (RDL) and a knee-flexion curl (preferably seated) to cover regional 
hamstring development along the proximal–distal axis.sciencedirect+1 
• Emphasize controlled eccentrics and long-range positions to leverage lengthened-tension 
mechanisms.sciencedirect+1 
keywords: hamstrings, RDL, leg curl, seated curl, lying curl, good morning, hip 
extension.sciencedirect+2 
citations:.sciencedirect+2 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-008 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Glutes 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Gluteus Maximus 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Barbell back squat: high-load global lower-body stimulus with glute hypertrophy 
similar to hip thrust under matched volume.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•

1. Barbell back squat: high-load global lower-body stimulus with glute hypertrophy 
similar to hip thrust under matched volume.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
2. Barbell hip thrust: glute emphasis with favorable stimulus-to-fatigue and reliable 
overload.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
3. Bulgarian split squat: unilateral long-length loading across glute and quad with large 
ROM.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
4. Step-up (hip hinge emphasis): strong hip extension demand through full 
extension.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
5. Romanian deadlift: glute–ham synergy at longer lengths complementing 
squat/thrust patterns.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
•  
6. Cable/banded kickback: accessory hip extension volume with low axial 
loading.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
programming_notes: 
• Rotate squat and hip thrust across phases or within weeks to diversify glute stimulus while 
managing axial fatigue.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
• Add a unilateral long-length movement to address stabilization and regional hypertrophy 
across hip angles.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
keywords: glutes, gluteus maximus, squat, hip thrust, split squat, step-up, 
kickback.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
citations:.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih+2 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START ===

chunk_id: HYPO-CH-009 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Calves 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Calves 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Seated calf raise: soleus emphasis with heavy loading and end-range dorsiflexion 
under tension.sciencedirect+1 
•  
2. Standing calf raise: gastrocnemius loading with progressive overload and full ankle 
ROM.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
3. Leg press calf raise: stable heavy sets minimizing balance constraints for higher 
volumes.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Single-leg calf raise: increased ROM and side-to-side balance under 
load.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Tibialis raise: anterior lower-leg development for balanced hypertrophy and injury 
resilience.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Train both seated and standing patterns weekly to target soleus and gastrocnemius while 
emphasizing loaded end-range.sciencedirect+1 
• Use slower eccentrics and peak contractions to improve tension quality at longer muscle 
lengths.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: calves, soleus, gastrocnemius, seated calf, standing calf, tibialis.sciencedirect+1 
citati

lity at longer muscle 
lengths.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: calves, soleus, gastrocnemius, seated calf, standing calf, tibialis.sciencedirect+1 
citations:.sciencedirect+1 
=== CHUNK END === 
=== CHUNK START === 
chunk_id: HYPO-CH-010 
title: Hypertrophy Rankings — Abs and Obliques 
goal: Hypertrophy 
muscle_group: Trunk Flexors and Obliques 
ranked_exercises: 
•  
1. Cable crunch: loadable spinal flexion with controlled range and 
progression.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
2. Machine crunch: bracing stability enabling proximity to failure in safer 
conditions.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
3. Hanging knee/leg raise (posterior pelvic tilt): better trunk flexor bias over hip flexor 
dominance.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
4. Decline bench crunch: increased resistance and consistent ROM for hypertrophy 
work.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
5. Pallof press and cable anti-rotation holds: progressive oblique tension with anti-
rotation emphasis.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
•  
6. Weighted side bend or cable side flexion: targeted oblique loading when lumbar 
tolerance allows.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Combine one loadable spinal flexion and one anti-rotation/rotation pattern for 
comprehensive trunk hypertrophy.pmc.ncbi.

m.nih 
programming_notes: 
• Combine one loadable spinal flexion and one anti-rotation/rotation pattern for 
comprehensive trunk hypertrophy.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Keep reps controlled and near failure to overcome lower absolute loading capacities in trunk 
work.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
keywords: abs, rectus abdominis, obliques, cable crunch, machine crunch, Pallof press, 
hanging raise.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
citations:.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
=== CHUNK END === 
Appendix — Evidence anchors 
• Hip thrust vs squat RCT: similar glute hypertrophy with divergent thigh regional outcomes 
under equated volume.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Technique and long-length emphasis review: exercise selection and ROM positioning to 
optimize hypertrophy stimulus.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• ROM and long-length partials study: context for prioritizing lengthened positions when 
practical.journal.iusca 
• Squat variations for quad strength/hypertrophy context: support for deep squatting and 
quad-dominant variants.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Glute hypertrophy overview and patterns: multiple exercises effective with programming 
considerations.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Rest intervals and hypertrophy programming context: small advantages for >60 s rests

effective with programming 
considerations.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• Rest intervals and hypertrophy programming context: small advantages for >60 s rests 
depending on context.pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih+1 
• RAG chunking best practices for retrievability schema and chunk design: balance granularity 
and context with rich metadata.dataforest+1 
Document metadata 
• corpus_title: Hypertrophy Exercise Rankings v1.0 — FAISS-Ready.arxiv 
• created: 2025-10-06.arxiv 
• scope: Adult healthy populations; adapt loads/ROM to individual tolerance and clinical 
status.pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih 
• intended_use: RAG retrieval for science-based workout generation; embeddings over chunk 
bodies + metadata filters by muscle_group, goal, and exercise.dataforest+1 
References used across chunks: technique and long-length positioning review, ROM/partials 
synthesis, squat vs hip thrust RCT, squat variation context, glute hypertrophy overview, lat pulldown 
to pull-up transfer, and rest-interval meta-analytic context for hypertrophy programming.
